body: Dispatch Router uses the Message Annotation x-opt-qd.trace (https://qpid.apache.org/releases/qpid-dispatch-0.8.0/book/book.html#amqp-mapping) as list of strings with all routers. So maybe something like x-opt-hono.trace might be nice.

For overall traceability it would be great to have such a tracing technology as opentracing.

But I still see a value for tracing information in the message itself (e.g. in annotations).

When there will be a system with all components involved, and all of them use such a system and also each customer/tenant is able to see (only) his message traces it might substitute the in-message information. 

But I would assume it might be easier in a lot of installations to also have such a in-message tracing.

> But I still see a value for tracing information in the message itself (e.g. in annotations).

What kind of information would that be for example?

- Component (adapter, messaging, router) and instance - to see the path, the message took
- Timestamp - to see the time consumed in each component/network part
- Configuration info - ssl in network and from device to adapter, ..
- System snapshot - open connections/cpu/ram

I think this all might be interesting in all variants of tracing. To put it in the message (if configured) is just one simple variant of bringing this information together and to scope it, because the message already has this 'trace'.
Well, I believe we can do all that with opentracing ...
